Freedoom

What is Freedoom?

Contents

  • Home Page
  • What is Freedoom?
  • Screenshots
  • Download
  • Fork me on GitHub
  • Report Issues
  • Discuss on the Forum
  • Talk on IRC

id Software released the source code to their classic game, Doom, under the GNU General Public License. This means that the engine which powers Doom is free software. However, the game engine is only one component of a complete game.

The Doom engine uses an IWAD file to store all of the game data. This contains the raw data used by the game — the artwork, sound effects, levels, and everything which defines Doom as a game. Until now, one of the original non-free files was still needed in order to play Doom.

The Freedoom project aims at collaboratively creating a free IWAD file. Combined with the source code, this results in a complete game based on the Doom engine.

The purpose of Freedoom

Freedoom has multiple purposes:

  1. To create a complete free game based on the Doom engine.
    A large library exists of modifications which have been created for Doom over the decades; Freedoom maintains compatibility with the original IWAD files so that this modifications can be played.

  2. To create a pool of free game material for people to reuse in their own projects.
    All material in the Freedoom project is released under a modified BSD license, allowing people to reuse it as they wish. Freedoom contains a large collection of material. This includes levels, sound effects, graphics, and music.

  3. To serve as a demonstration of the talent and creativity of the Doom community.
    Despite its age, Doom has retained a surprisingly large community of fans. Freedoom is developed collaboratively by fans of the original Doom games.
